title: 15+ Ways to Celebrate Women History Month in Raleigh for 2023
body_text:
As a mother of two daughters, and someone who has worked hard to push against male defined ceilings to create a thriving life I love, celebrating the achievements of women and our powerful voices is very important to me.
March is Women‚Äôs History Month, a month dedicated to celebrating women‚Äôs contributions to history, culture and society.
Women‚Äôs History Month is a time to celebrate and rejoice in womanhood, but to also look at the injustices we still face and how we can work for a more equitable society.
I love that we have an entire month dedicated to remembering to give that little extra support to voices that typically are rooted in nurturing peace, love, and joy.
Empowering women is a benefit to societies, and I find Raleigh does a pretty good job at it, and it‚Äôs only getting better.
In this guide, we share all the ways you can celebrate Women‚Äôs History Month in Raleigh, from shopping at women-owned stores to attending events specifically for WHM!
The History of ‚ÄúWomen‚Äôs History Month‚Äù
Women‚Äôs History Month grew out of a week-long celebration that was organized by the school district of Sonoma, California in 1978.
The idea soon caught on and spread across the country until President Jimmy Carter declared the week of March 8 as National Women‚Äôs History Week. Six years later it was expanded by Congress to the entire month of March.
Falling within this month is International Women‚Äôs Day, a global celebration of the economic, political and social achievements of women, which took place for the first time on March 8, 1911.
International Women‚Äôs Day Events
- International Women‚Äôs Day Expo at the Raleigh Convention Center 11am ‚Äì 5pm FREE speakers from accomplished entrepreneurs and businesswomen in Raleigh, as well as informative workshops, and a wide range of exhibitors showcasing products and services that support women‚Äôs well-being and women owned businesses.
- Quarrel for the Crown: Empowering Women to Rise & Reign Raleigh Convention Center Amateur female boxers from diverse backgrounds, competing to highlight their skills.
- Cermaic artist Andr√©a Keys Connell will discuss her solo exhibition Mom on view at Artspace (until April 27) and talk about art, memory, and family. 12pm ‚Äì 1pm FREE
- Women Behind the Bottle ‚Äì Free Guided Non-alcoholic Spirit Tasting at the Self Care Marketplace Enoy tasting non-alcoholic drinks and spirits crafted by inspiring women founders who are leading the way in the beverage industry. 11am ‚Äì 2pm
- Women‚Äôs History Tour Learn about the incredible women who helped make Raleigh the fabulous city that it is today on this guided walking tour! 11am ‚Äì 12:15pm Pay what you want.
- 12th Anniversary Party at Raleigh Brewing Celebrating 12 years of this favorite woman-owned local brewery. Specialty beer releases, food Trucks, live music by Say Less and Your Mama‚Äôs New Boyfriend, Keg Hoisting Competition and after party karaoke. 12pm ‚Äì 10pm
- Women-in-Beer Tour in Holly Springs starting at Bombshell Brewing $50 1- 3:30pm
- First Friday in Downtown Raleigh with the Feminist ‚Äì Women‚Äôs History Month theme. Come and support local artisans and business. See our guide to First Friday in Raleigh with a list of the events happening.
The 2025 Theme for Women‚Äôs History Month
The Women‚Äôs History Month theme for 2025 is ‚ÄúMoving Forward Together! Women Educating & Inspiring Generations.‚Äù
The theme, which was declared by the National Women‚Äôs History Alliance (NWHA), recognizes women throughout the country who understand that, for a positive future, we need to eliminate bias and discrimination entirely from our lives and institutions, but also that education is key to moving forward in this.
In 2025, we pay tribute to the remarkable women in our community, both historical and contemporary, who have courageously led the way in advocating for change and instituting stronger protections, norms, and laws that embody these principles.
After enduring years of discrimination, we take pride in honoring the women dedicated to advancing fundamental values of inclusion, equality, and justice.
Check out our post on 14 women-owned businesses in Downtown Raleigh telling great stories.
Ideas For Celebrating Women‚Äôs History Month In Raleigh
Now we shall share ways you can celebrate women this month, including great local women-owned business in Raleigh you can support.
Share your thoughts and suggestions in the comments. Include your favorite female creatives, artists, business owners, friends and why you love them!
Learn the history of women in Raleigh
There are many places where you can learn about women in Raleigh and their contributions to the community and growth of the city.
- Go on a Raleigh Women‚Äôs History Walking tour. Every Saturday throughout the month of March, you can go on a pay-what-you-want (recommended $15) walking tour of Raleigh which takes you around historic sites and focuses specifically on the incredible women who shaped the Raleigh we see today, including the city‚Äôs first female mayor, one of the most influential women in the civil rights movement, and the woman who earned the nickname ‚ÄúLady Edison‚Äù because of her numerous inventions! Sign up for tickets here.
- There is an exhibition, Women of Change: The Legacy of the 19th Amendment at the COR Museum. It chronicles the quests for equal suffrage in 1920 and what women did with the vote over the next century. Visitors will be introduced to Raleigh‚Äôs suffragists, organizers, and elected officials who redefined women‚Äôs role in politics.
- Also, at the NC Museum of History, which is currently closed for renovations, has a Women Making History in North Carolina digital exhibit showcasing the contributions of women from our past. See more here.
Read more: 8 Fantastic Museums in Raleigh (most are free!)
Attend Grace & Growth: Women‚Äôs Empowerment Brunch
- Where: The Hibiscus Raleigh
- Time: 11am ‚Äì 2pm
- Cost: $55+
- Tickets
Grace & Growth is more than just a brunch‚Äîit‚Äôs a powerful gathering dedicated to honoring women for their hard work, resilience, and contributions to their families, careers, and communities.
From mothers, caregivers, and teachers to entrepreneurs, creatives, and community leaders, this is a space for women to be recognized, poured into, and celebrated.
The event will feature a live podcast recording of Perfectly Poured featuring inspirational conversations, a networking experience, and an unforgettable moment of honoring impactful women. . VIP options include swag bags, floral gifts, and professional headshots!
I‚Äôm looking forward to attending and saying a few words of encouragement at the beginning to help inspire and empower!
Dine at these amazing women-owned restaurants + foodies
- Ashely Christensen needs no introduction in Raleigh. A James Beard Award winner and owner of the speakeasy, Fox Liquor Bar! And 4 outstanding iconic Raleigh restaurants
- Beasley‚Äôs Chicken + Honey
- Death & Taxes
- Poole‚Äôs Diner
- Sara Coleman Fitzpatrick is the owner of The Cupcake Shoppe Bakery, Raleigh‚Äôs first cupcake shop! Located on Glenwood Ave you‚Äôll find freshly baked cupcakes, homemade batch of cookies, a cup of locally roasted Joe Van Gogh coffee, paired with a calming ambiance. Her cupcakes are delicious, and she even has gluten free and vegan.
- A transformative visit to Mexico inspired Angela Salamanca to bring a taste of Oaxaca to Raleigh, North Carolina. Centro Mexican Restaurant has become a staple in downtown Raleigh, and they take pride in being a space that fosters community and diversity. I LOVE the mezcal bar upstairs, Gallo Pel√≥n.
- Known to have one of the best masala chairs in Raleigh and delicious homemade Indian Food, Cheeni in North Raleigh is owned by Preeti, who was born and raised in South India. I LOVE the vibe of this restaurant. As soon as I walked in I was transported back to my days backpacking Asia. I only had a snack of a very memorable Aloo chaat. I‚Äôll be back.
- Mofu Dumpling Shoppe has its beginnings with business partners Sunny Linn and Sophia Woo and their popular food truck, The Pho Nomenal Dumpling Truck. You‚Äôll find a menu of reimagined Asian classics. When I need a taste of Asia, I come here.
- While not a restaurant, one cannot call themselves a Raleigh resident until they‚Äôve eaten a lemon meringue or pumpkin pie from Slice of Pie Company. Founder (and true Raleigh local) Kristen Mullins really proves she is the Pie Lady with the diversity of her homemade pies and bona fide deliciousness of them. She even has gluten free!
- Caroline Morrison and Siobhan Southern, are the co-owners of Raleigh‚Äôs Fiction Kitchen. Not only does Fiction Kitchen serve delicious food from their all-vegan menu, but they also have a business that is all about inclusivity. Y‚Äôall are truly welcome here at this iconic Raleigh restaurant.
- Originally from the Bahamas, Randi is obsessed with beautiful cake creations. You can find them at her store Sugar Euphoria in the North Person St area.
- I tasted the chocolates from Spring & Mulberry at the Boylan Art Walk, and they were delicious (and healthy!) Owners Kathryn Shah and Sarah Bell create date-sweetened chocolate with fantastic-for-you flavors that showcase the depth and spectrum of ‚Äúsweet‚Äù found in whole, pristine ingredients.
- Flavors Ice cream on Jones Franklin serves SUPER PREMIUM ice cream. Owner Elisa McLean is an inspiration, not only for bringing joy to community via ice cream but also running her business as a single mother and a brain tumor cancer survivor.
- Clyde Coopers Barbecue ‚Äì an iconic Raleigh staple since 1938 ‚Äì is owned by mother-daughter duo, by Debbie Wray and Ashley Jessup who took over the restaurant in 2008.
Support these women-owned non-profit organizations
The following local non-profit organizations working to create a better Raleigh are all female owned. You can support them via donations, shopping in their stores, volunteering, or just spreading their good work.
- Maggie Kane is the Founder and Executive Director of A Place at the Table, Raleigh‚Äôs pay-what-you-can cafe helping those experiencing homelessness in our community. (listen to our podcast interview with Founder Maggie Kane)
- Cary Heise / Kristen Sydow are co-founders of Designed for Joy where they provide second chance employment to vulnerable women. Artisans are paid a living wage and taught skills to create the Designed for Joy brand of jewelry, handbags, and home decor. Listen to our podcast interview with Cary Heise here and here is more about their annual fundraising event Evening of Giving.
- Co-founder, and CEO of Carroll‚Äôs Kitchen, Vicki Ismail is using her non-profit restaurant to provide women recovering from addiction, homelessness, incarceration, and domestic violence with employment. Caroll‚Äôs Kitchen on Martin St offers grab-and-go breakfast & lunch.
- Mother and daughter team, Mary and Gabi currently have over 40 employees with special abilities at their 2 nonprofit companies: Gabi‚Äôs Grounds & Gab‚Äôs PALS. They don‚Äôt just have their private label coffee blends, but a packaging, assembling and shipping service for businesses.
- No Woman No Girl: Fantastic local non-profit founded by Shirnetta J Harrell to provide essential items to those women and girls in our community at risk.
- NWNG) will host its third annual Bringing H.O.P.E. Women‚Äôs Day event on March 22 from 11am ‚Äì 2pm at the Boys & Girls Club (605 Raleigh Blvd. Raleigh, NC 27610). This free, interactive event will provide onsite health and wellness support to women, girls, and families. WNG will offer attendees free supplies of everyday hygiene essentials, while partnering agencies will provide clothing, housing, medical, full-sized menstruation hygiene products (tampons, pads, liners, and sanitary wipes), mental health and other critical resources to address urgent needs within the Triangle. The family-friendly event will also feature free food from local vendors, a DJ, and engaging activities to create connection, spark conversation, and promote a stronger, more inclusive community.
- Jackie Craig and Beth Smoot founded The Green Chair Project in 2010 to collect and reuse essential furnishings to benefit their Wake County neighbors in need.
- Esteamed Coffee is a non-profit coffee shop and cafe located in Cary, NC who employs individuals with various disabilities. Co-founders, Angie Hudson and Tamara Lapsley provide job coaching and a supportive/encouraging environment where the employees and patrons feel they are part of a warm, welcoming community.
- Local 321 Coffee in Downtown Raleigh employs 50+ employees with intellectual and developmental disabilities who all roasting the coffee, take the orders, and make the lattes. They also have locations in the State Farmers Market and Durham.
Shop at women-owned stores
Raleigh is full of diverse, women owned businesses and entrepreneurs. In fact, 46% of businesses in Downtown Raleigh are women-owned, this is in comparison to the state average of 21% and the country‚Äôs 19.9% (State of Downtown Raleigh 2023 report).
Here is another celebratory fact: in 2022, Raleigh was named the best city for working women in the nation?
According to Coworking Cafe, Raleigh is the second-best large metro for women in tech in the USA and the unemployment rate among female workers is one of the lowest in the country at less than 3%. Is there a list Raleigh is not on?
There are so many local businesses in Raleigh that you can support with your dollars. Here are a few of our favorite women-owned stores.
- The Flourish Market in the Iron Works District is a unique women‚Äôs + gift boutique store owned by local entrepreneur, Emily Grey. All of their products have a higher purpose for supporting female owned businesses creating sustainable impact.
- Deco Raleigh owner Pam Blondin opened the shop in 2012 with the intention to support locals. She stocks hundreds of locally made gifts, housewares, books and cards from more than 75 local artisans and makers.
- Rose & Lee Co Boutique in Apex Amber Rose and Prisca Lee are the founders of this cute store in Downtown Apex. They feature brands (many local), each with their own mission of change and empowerment, from sustainability to human rights. I‚Äôm a regular shopper here!
- The Bath Place at Pop-Up Shops at Martin Street has divine candles and handcrafted, spa-quality, natural soaps. Founder, Kimberly Clayton also has an online store.
- Edge of Urge in North Person St is owned by Jessie Williams. They specialize in handmade and independent designer clothing, shoes, jewelry and accessories.
- Munjo Munjo is owned and operated by a Latinx artist. This design studio highlights women and BIPOC artists, through collaborative works, live art events, and other opportunities.
- Nashona Boutique. The beautiful prints and textiles of Tanzania have created this unique clothing line from Lilian Danieli, a Tanzanian native who now resides in North Carolina.
- Triangle Pop-Up founder Sarah Moody local pop-up events and vendor markets in the area supporting local businesses. She also has a storefront Curate on E Hargett St that features a unique collection of handmade goods which included candles, jewelry and homemade sauces from over 60 local artists.
- Anne‚Äôs Apothecary a skincare brand owned by Anne Suinner-Lawoyin that offers 100% clean, eco-friendly, plant-based skincare products at affordable prices.
- Designed for Joy will be having a She Means Business ‚Äì Women‚Äôs History Month market on March 20 at their downtown store to support local women business owners.
Cheers to female drink crafters
It‚Äôs not just mean making waves in the craft brew scene. Many women are innovating in the space of beers, wine, cocktails, and coffee. Let‚Äôs give an extra cheer to them this month!
- Raleigh Brewing was the first female owned brewery in NC with Kristie Nystedt as majority owner. It‚Äôs their 11th anniversary party on Sat March 9th. (Don‚Äôt miss our suggestions things to do each weekend in Raleigh.
- Lindsay Rice owns the Vita Vite Wine Bar and Gallery in the Warehouse District and North Hills. Vita Vite comes from the Italian words for ‚Äúlife‚Äù and ‚Äúvine‚Äù ‚Äì the idea of life revolving around wine and food, and how they bring people together in a common space of appreciation for the beautiful things that can enrich life. (Read our interview with owner Lindsay Rice)
- Bombshell Beer Company in Holly Springs is owned by three female brewers who love to remind us that until Medieval times, it was the woman‚Äôs job to brew beer for the household and laws of that time stated that the tools of brewing were solely the woman‚Äôs property.
- Tiffany Welton opened RBF Champagne Bar in Downtown Cary dedicated to honoring women‚Äôs authentic self. Show up with any face you like, and you‚Äôll be honored.
- DRINK on Glenwood Ave claims itself as more of a small wine society of friends than a wine shop. They specialize in small production wines and invite you into their intimate tasting space, outdoor seating and a Fine Wine ‚ÄúCave‚Äù. I love the peacock mural on the outside of the building.
- What about a dessert and cocktail bar? Yes. Please. Head to Bittersweet in downtown Raleigh owned by Kim Hammer. It‚Äôs where you‚Äôll find one of my favorite pairings: Pumpkin creme brulee and Irish coffee.
- Looking for some bitters for your cocktails? Crude Bitters and Sodas was founded in 2012 as the first cocktail bitters company in North Carolina. Owners Craig Rudewicz and Lindsay Lasserre, They have a shop front in Downtown Raleigh near Transfer Food Hall.
- What about cold brew? You may have seen, or tasted, the creamy goodness of Slingshot Coffee in a can at your local grocery store. It was founded in 2012 by local Jenny Bonchak.
- Lashonda Fort-Modest, is the owner of Melanated Wines & Spirits, Durham‚Äôs first Black-owned winery. She aims to decomplicate wine, embody the motto, ‚Äúuncork the culture,‚Äù and represent the under-represented minority community in the world of wine.
- Local 321 Coffee was founded in 2017 by Lindsay Wrege and Michael Evans to embrace diversity to its fullest. Apart from providing great coffee to the Raleigh community they employ 50+ employees with intellectual and developmental disabilities.
Watch women‚Äôs sports
We love to support women‚Äôs sport, and just like the men‚Äôs version, we have a lot of options in Raleigh with our Triangle colleges, and professional NC Courage team. Women‚Äôs sports are just as exciting, skillful, fast and intense as men‚Äôs.
The ACC Women‚Äôs Basketball Tournament games will start on Wednesday, March 5-9 in Greensboro and the championship will determine the ACC‚Äôs automatic entry to the NCAA tourney.
We are avid fans of watching the NC State women‚Äôs basketball at the gorgeous art deco Reynolds Coliseum and are regulars at the women‚Äôs soccer at WakeMed Park in Cary.
The North Carolina Courage women‚Äôs soccer will start their 2025 NWSL Regular Season this month with a game against vs Racing Louisville on March 15, 2025, at Lynn Family Stadium, Louisville, KY, and their first home game in WHM is Saturday March 22, 2025, against Seattle Reign FC.
Don‚Äôt dismiss the women‚Äôs college soccer teams. UNC‚Äôs run for the NCAA title last year was an on-the-edge of your seat game to remember!
Read our guide to the Wake Med Soccer Park, see our Reel of NC State Women‚Äôs Basketball in action, and the UNC women‚Äôs soccer team.
Explore Women in the Arts
Raleigh has a thriving art scene for all kinds of mediums and styles. You can easily find an exhibition in Raleigh celebrating the artistic talents of local female artists. It doesn‚Äôt even have to be local, just support a women‚Äôs voice expressed through art.
There are concerts, live music, standup comedians, art galleries, theater productions, and so much more. Here are a few ideas:
- First Friday is a fantastic opportunity to explore the different art galleries in Raleigh and their exhibition and fun events. This month will be March 7, 2025, and will be the theme of Feminist First Friday.
- The aforementioned Vita Vite Gallery, which regularly has art exhibitions and is fun to combine with a wine of First Friday.
- 311 Gallery in the warehouse District has 12 artist‚Äôs studios as well as a gift shop in the front and an exhibition gallery out front, which changes every month with the First Friday opening reception.
- Why not take a day trip to Johnston County and visit the excellent Ava Gardner Museum and her incredible contribution to the world of film?
- Don‚Äôt forget perusing female works in the outstanding North Carolina Museum of Art. Also, the spectacular Art in Bloom festival is on at NCMA, which will have many female artists represented.
- Look around as you‚Äôre walking through Downtown Raleigh and neighborhoods across the Triangle. You‚Äôre bound to see some beautiful murals, many of which will be the work of female artists.
Don‚Äôt miss these art museums and art galleries in Raleigh for an educational activity day!
Hear the stories of your female loved ones
Always start with those closest to you, family, friends, work associates. Especially as this year‚Äôs theme encourages collaboration and community.
Spend time this month to hear their stories. How can you honor them? What can you learn from them? How can you pass it and pay it forward?
Although women‚Äôs rights are much better now, they weren‚Äôt always this way. It‚Äôs quite inspirational talking to your grandmother or other women of the older generation to hear about how times have changed for them.
Donate to a Women‚Äôs Rights Organization
You can help promote social justice for women around the world through monetary donations. Consider the above-mentioned organizations by North Carolina residents. Here are a few highlighted organizations that strive for the global empowerment of women:
- The United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women
- Rise Up Women International
- Association for Women‚Äôs Rights in Development
- Center for Reproductive Rights
- Equality Now
Host an event to celebrate women
Gather your women friends to learn, create, and celebrate together. Here are a few ideas you can do with your female friends:
- A movie might watching female directed films or those with female leads (Hello Barbie! Trailblazing Smash hit of 2023)
- Create artwork together ‚Äì perhaps murals of empowering female quotes.
- Play music by female artists ‚Äì and of course, bust out in your best Beyonce moves (speaking of who, I love her new Texas Hold Em Song)
- Give out awards, achievements, positive notes of affirmations to you gal pals.
- Discuss what sisterhood means and how y‚Äôall can make it better.
- Host book clubs with books written by women.
- Watch TED Talks given by women. Check out this one by Raleigh local, and former WRAL Anchor, Mikaya Thurmond on Human Touch in an AI World: Authenticity in Public Relations
- Attend a fun woman focused event
Educate and empower yourself
There‚Äôs no better way to ensure a better future for our daughters then to educate and empower yourself, especially as this year‚Äôs theme focuses on education.
Learn more about the current issues that affect women, so you are better able to help create solutions.
Learn how to believe in, and trust in your own voice and story. Develop the confidence and courage to share your story with the world ‚Äì if you positively impact just one person, you‚Äôve made a difference.
- The NC State University Women‚Äôs Center is kicking off WHM with a HERstory event on the 28th of February. The event brings together women from the community to share workshops, discussions and other events to honor the contributions of women. You can join here.
- The Raleigh Chamber of Commerce is hosting the ‚ÄúWomen‚Äôs Leadership Conference‚Äù on March 25th. The theme is ‚ÄúChampions of Change‚Äù and shines the spotlight on female businesses in Raleigh, including an inclusive business networking meetup to support and celebrate our diverse workforce. Sign up here.
- NC Vibes will host its 3rd annual International Women‚Äôs Day Expo at The Raleigh Convention Center on Sat March 8 with a variety of speakers from accomplished entrepreneurs and businesswomen in Raleigh.
Volunteer to help women in need
In addition to the above, here are a few more women‚Äôs organizations that are looking for volunteers in the Triangle Area.
- Women‚Äôs Center of Wake County
- The Women‚Äôs Club of Raleigh
- Interact Family Safety and Empowerment Center
- Dress for Success Triangle NC
- SHE NC
- 100 Women Who Give A Hoot is a membership giving circle that supports local nonprofits in the greater Raleigh area. They have a sister program for the men, 100 Men who give a damn.
Make self-care a priority (with these women owned business to help)
There‚Äôs never a better time to prioritize your health than a month focused on supporting women. Get your annual checkup including relevant pap smears, mammograms and whatever else you need!
Start eating cleaner and move your body! Here are some fantastic women-owned wellness businesses to help!
- Well Centered Wellness is our go-to for all things wellness related. Dr Allison Peters has spent the last 17 years in practice as a nutrition-based chiropractic physician specializing in functional nutrition, amputation and traumatic brain injury recovery and human potential neurological optimization. You can listen to our podcast interview with Dr Allison here. She is responsible for helping me lose 25lbs in 2023 and, so far, keep it off! Sadly, in 2023 Dr Allison suffered a traumatic spinal injury, and while is not personally seeing patients as she is busy learning to walk again, she has many of her programs still running. She is the most inspirational and resilient person you‚Äôll ever meet so follow her journey to miraculous recovery.
- I love all that Current Wellness does to support health and wellness in the Raleigh community. Owned by Britt and her husband, they offer a range of movement, cooking, and nutrition classes, as well as fun events and services like massage therapy.
- Raleigh locals Katie Clemons and Jolene Johnson own Yoga Soullective in the Warehouse District. They also run yoga retreats! This month it‚Äôs in Tulum!
- Emily Wallace owns DOSE Hot Yoga and Smoothie Bar in the new Smokey Hollow Development and newly opened Innovation District in North Hills. They also have teacher training, wellness events, and yoga retreats (hello Bali!)
- Providing wellness solutions to the Triangle Community through organic hair care and Infrared Sauna services is Kristina Graham from Rize Salon and Infrared in Cary. We use the infrared sauna at least once a week.
- Marina Lando from Harmony Life Reiki in Cary has been my monthly Reiki healer for years and is what I call my monthly non-negotiable! Marina is the author of four books, is a Reiki Master and Teacher, and Certified Aromatherapist,
Listen to our podcast on health and wellness businesses we love in Raleigh and our interview with Dr Allison Peters.
Clean the air in your house with help from these Plant Bosses
Life is just better when you‚Äôre surrounded by plants: Better quality of air, pretty spaces, and Zen-like vibes are just some of the benefits!
Here are three female plant experts in Raleigh to go to for help to ensure you find the right fit for you:
- Raleigh native, Anna Grace is the owner of Copperline Plant Co in the City Market district. Not only does she have a store filled with gorgeous plants, but she also offers plant consultations, and monthly plant-based classes.
- TG Floristry is a Black woman-owned, Raleigh-based floral design studio, owned and operated by Tiera George. Itera has participated in Art in Bloom (on this March in Raleigh) and she offers creative workshops!
Join a women‚Äôs organization or club
There are plenty of women-centric organizations and clubs in Raleigh. From educational, to networking, emotional support and just fun sisterhood times, there are clubs to suit all types and missions.
- Raleigh Women in Marketing is a women‚Äôs networking community to connect, network, and inspire those in the marketing realm!
- Raleigh Chamber of Commerce has initiatives and groups focused on women in leadership and Triangle Diversity, Equity & Inclusivity Alliance
- Thrive Motherhood is a community for moms with mom-only events designed to help them thrive in and out of home.
- The National Association of Women Business Owners has a chapter in Raleigh. It‚Äôs a premier member-based organization for business acceleration resources, leadership development opportunities and inspiring programs that empower, equip and propel women business owners.
- Blush Coworking Space in Cary is a women‚Äôs only co-working space, which clearly shows they understand women, with their on-site childcare services!
- Women‚Äôs Social Club is a club in Raleigh where women can come together at fun events to connect with other women and learn more about the city they live in.
- Crowded Table has themed events to help women connect and have fun!
- Junior League of Raleigh is for women interested in volunteerism, advancing women‚Äôs leadership, and a commitment to improving our community.
- Raleigh Women in Tech Use this group to grow your skills both professionally and technically, discuss the issues facing our field, and share skills and experiences with other individuals who identify as women here in Raleigh.
- Triangle Women Entrepreneurs: Offers a place to connect, celebrate, and build collaborations between women in business in the Triangle region of central North Carolina.
- Women in Networking (WIN): With multiple chapters in the Triangle, WIN provides a supportive community for women business owners and professionals to exchange customer referrals, leads, share knowledge and offer support.
- Raleigh Women in Marketing A Community for Raleigh Women In Marketing to connect, network, and inspire!
- Unruly Women Collective supports female entrepreneurs and professionals grow together through small group meet-ups, ticketed events, community pop-up markets, and gather to give back to local non-profits.
- Working Mothers of RaleighA monthly meetup group designed toempower, energize, and enable working moms in the area to meet their full potential at work and a home.
- The Junior League of Raleigh is an organization whose mission is to advance women‚Äôs leadership for meaningful community impact through volunteer action, collaboration, and training. Its purpose is exclusively educational and charitable.
- Dress for Success Triangle NC empowers women to achieve economic independence by providing a network of support, professional attire, networking and the development tools to help women thrive in work and life.
Other women in Raleigh you want to hear about
Here are some other female trailblazers in Raleigh you‚Äôll want to know. I‚Äôll continue to add to this list as there are so many to love and we‚Äôre always meeting new people and hearing cool stories.
- Susan from Experience Raleigh has become a great Raleigh influencer friend of ours over the past few months. We see her at many events and love her warm, friendly, happy spirit. Plus, she‚Äôs a true Raleigh native and shares all about our beautiful city on her Instagram.
- Adrienne Cole ‚Äì the first (and current) female CEO of the Raleigh Chamber of Commerce. We adore Adrienne, and feel Raleigh is so blessed to have such an energetic, passionate, compassionate, and friendly leader for the Raleigh business community. You can listen to our podcast interview with Adrienne here.
- Kiara Ruth from BananaMoon is a mommy blogger, lifestyle influencer, and thought leader who, along with her husband Terrance, are committed to creating positive social change that is representative of all. Listen to our podcast interview with them here.
- April Blackwell from Blackwell Mortgage was our mortgage broker helping us attain a mortgage when we thought it couldn‚Äôt happen. She‚Äôs not only savvy with finance, but has a positive, joyful spirit that you want to be around. Listen to our podcast interview with her here. (With tips for getting mortgage finance!)
- Mikaya Thurmond. You may remember her as the weekday morning anchor for WRAL! She left there to pursue a career in Public Relations. We have such high admiration and respect for Mikaya and her company, Milan Public Relations.
- Sarah Rosa Glickman Art is a local artist known for her POSCA paintings, colorful abstract art, and black and white line art work. You can see more of her work online here.
Comment: Who are your favorite female creatives, artists, business owners, friends etc. and share why you love them? What are some other ways you will celebrate Women‚Äôs History Month in Raleigh this year?
